Introduction

Cannabis use disorder is characterized by the overuse of cannabis (marijuana) despite negative consequences to health, relationships, or daily functioning.  The primary psychoactive compound in cannabis, tetrahydrocannabinol, produces effects, including euphoria, relaxation, and altered perception.  Chronic or heavy cannabis use can lead to dependence and withdrawal symptoms and is associated with impairments in motivation, memory, and academic or occupational performance.

Pharmacology



Cannabis is a genus of flowering plants that contains many active compounds, most notably delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), which is responsible for its psychoactive effects (eg, euphoria, relaxation).  THC exerts these effects mainly by binding to cannabinoid (CB1) receptors in the CNS, influencing neurotransmitters such as dopamine, GABA, and glutamate.  Cannabidiol (CBD), another natural cannabinoid, is nonintoxicating but has antianxiety, anti-inflammatory, and neuroprotective properties.



Synthetic cannabinoids are laboratory-made compounds designed to activate the same receptors as THC.  Although some are developed for clinical use (eg, chronic pain, chemotherapy-induced nausea), many are manufactured illicitly and marketed as recreational drugs (eg, K2, Spice).  Although synthetics can mimic the effects of natural cannabis, illicitly produced cannabinoids are often significantly more potent, longer-lasting, and unpredictable.



Cannabis is metabolized in the liver, distributed and stored in lipophilic tissues, and slowly released.  Depending on the amount and frequency of use, it can be detected in the urine up to 30 days after daily use has ceased.

Epidemiology and risk factors



Recreational use of marijuana is common, and cannabis is the most widely used recreational substance globally.  Its use is particularly prevalent among young adults (age 18-25) and male individuals.  Risk factors associated with developing cannabis use disorder include:



  • Early age of initiation (especially age <18).
  • Frequent (daily or near-daily) or prolonged duration of use, particularly at higher potencies.
  • Family history of substance use disorders.
  • Coexisting psychiatric disorders:  Depression, anxiety, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, schizophrenia.

Pathogenesis



Chronic exposure to THC or synthetic cannabinoids leads to the downregulation and desensitization of CB1 receptors in the brain, particularly in areas responsible for reward, memory, and emotional regulation.  This contributes to the development of tolerance, dependence, and persistent use of cannabis despite negative consequences or functional impairment.



The systemic effects of long-term cannabis use are widespread and may involve the following organ systems (

):



  • Pulmonary:  Cannabis smoke can trigger airway hyperreactivity and bronchoconstriction, leading to increased asthma exacerbations.  Although cannabis itself causes bronchodilation, this effect allows smoke to reach smaller airways, causing more airway reactivity.
  • Gastrointestinal:  Cannabis hyperemesis syndrome involves recurrent episodes of nausea, intractable vomiting, and generalized abdominal pain.  The symptoms are characteristically improved with hot showers or baths and resolve within 1-2 days of drug abstinence.
  • Reproductive:  Prolonged cannabis use may alter the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis and reduce sperm production and motility.
  • Neuropsychiatric:  Chronic cannabis use may lead to apathy, cognitive impairment, memory deficits, and decreased intelligence with poor performance at work/school.  Cannabis also increases the risk for psychosis and mood disorders, especially in those with a predisposition to psychiatric illness.

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of cannabis use disorder relies on a thorough history to evaluate patterns of consumption (eg, quantity, frequency) and to assess the functional and psychologic consequences of its use.  Patients must have â‰¥2 of the following within a 12-month period:



  • Taking larger amounts or using for a longer time than intended.
  • Persistent desire for and an inability to cut down or control use.
  • Excessive time spent obtaining, using, or recovering from cannabis.
  • Strong cravings.
  • Recurrent use resulting in a failure to fulfill major role obligations at work, school, or home.
  • Continued use despite persistent social or interpersonal problems.
  • Neglecting or giving up of important social, occupational, or recreational activities because of cannabis use.
  • Recurrent use of cannabis in hazardous situations (eg, driving under the influence).
  • Tolerance:  Need for increased amounts to achieve desired effects.
  • Withdrawal symptoms when use is reduced or stopped.

Cannabis intoxication



Recreational cannabis is most commonly smoked, but it can also be inhaled via vaporization (eg, e-cigarettes) or ingested orally (eg, edibles).  Inhalation produces a rapid onset of psychoactive effects (within minutes), and the effects last 2-4 hours.  Oral ingestion is associated with a delayed onset and prolonged duration; psychoactive effects begin 30 minutes to 3 hours after consumption and last up to 12 hours.

Clinical presentation



Acute intoxication presents with the following clinical manifestations (

):



Psychologic/neurologic symptoms:



  • Euphoria and relaxation.
  • Altered perception of time.
  • Impaired attention, concentration, and short-term memory.
  • Psychomotor retardation.
  • Anxiety, panic, and paranoia, which are more likely in first-time users or individuals using high doses or synthetics.  Hallucinations, paranoia, or delusions can also occur with high doses.


Physical examination findings:



  • Drowsiness, fatigue.
  • Conjunctival injection (red eyes).
  • Tachycardia, tachypnea.
  • Increased appetite ("munchies").
  • Dry mouth.


Pediatric intoxication is characterized mainly by neurologic abnormalities, including ataxia, purposeless motor movements, lethargy, seizures, and coma.

Differential diagnosis



  • Alcohol intoxication:  Can lead to disinhibited behavior, drowsiness, and impaired attention, but patients typically have an identifiable odor of alcohol on their breath, and intoxication can be confirmed by obtaining a blood ethanol level.
  • Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) intoxication:  Produces euphoria, an altered sense of time and space, and tachycardia.  However, vivid visual hallucinations characteristic of this potent hallucinogen are not expected with cannabis intoxication.
  • Opioid intoxication:  Typically presents with euphoria and depressed mental status, but, unlike cannabis, opioids lower the heart and respiratory rates, and the symptoms are rapidly reversed with naloxone administration.

Diagnosis



Acute cannabis intoxication is diagnosed primarily based on typical clinical manifestations and a history of recent use.  Although urine drug screening can detect THC, a positive result does not confirm acute intoxication; THC metabolites may remain detectable for days to weeks after use.



Laboratory evaluation and imaging studies are not required for diagnosis.

Management



Supportive care is usually sufficient for managing acute intoxication.  Patients experiencing anxiety or paranoia should be reassured and placed in a calm environment.  Benzodiazepines (eg, lorazepam) may be administered in cases of severe agitation or panic.

Cannabis withdrawal



Withdrawal symptoms typically manifest within a week following the cessation or reduction of prolonged and/or heavy cannabis use (eg, daily use for months).  The clinical signs typically begin within 24-72 hours of last use, peak in 2-6 days, and resolve within 1-2 weeks.  Symptoms are generally mild and not life-threatening but may cause distress and contribute to relapse (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
).  Synthetic cannabinoids cause longer-lasting and more severe physiologic and psychologic disturbances compared to natural cannabis.

Clinical presentation



  • Psychologic symptoms:

    • Irritability, agitation, anger.
    • Anxiety, restlessness.
    • Depression.
    • Insomnia or vivid dreams.
    • Craving for cannabis.
  • Physical symptoms:
    • Headache.
    • Decreased appetite and weight loss.
    • Abdominal pain or discomfort.
    • Fever, chills.
    • Autonomic hyperactivity (eg, tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis), seizures, and delirium:  More likely with synthetic cannabinoid withdrawal.

Differential diagnosis



  • Cocaine withdrawal:  Similar to cannabis withdrawal, cocaine withdrawal may present with dysphoria, irritability, and anxiety.  However, cocaine withdrawal is typically characterized by hyperphagia (increased appetite) and hypersomnia (excessive sleepiness), rather than the reduced appetite and insomnia seen in cannabis withdrawal.
  • Opioid withdrawal:  Withdrawal from opioids can also cause dysphoria and irritability but is more distinctly associated with severe gastrointestinal symptoms such as vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal cramping, and muscle aches.  Characteristic physical examination findings include mydriasis, piloerection, and lacrimation, which are not features of cannabis withdrawal.
  • Major depressive disorder (MDD):  Although depressed mood may occur during cannabis withdrawal, a diagnosis of MDD requires a broader constellation of symptoms (eg, anhedonia, low energy, impaired concentration, feelings of guilt, suicidal ideation) that persist for at least 2 weeks and are not directly tied to substance cessation.

Diagnosis



Cannabis withdrawal is diagnosed clinically based on the following criteria:



  • â‰¥3 withdrawal symptoms within 1 week of stopping cannabis use.
  • Symptoms that cause distress or impairment in function (eg, social, occupational).
  • Not attributable to another condition.


Laboratory testing and imaging studies are not required for diagnosis.

Management



Most symptoms of withdrawal are mild and resolve spontaneously without treatment.  Patients with bothersome symptoms may benefit from engaging in physical exercise, meditation, group therapy, or psychotherapy (eg, cognitive-behavioral therapy [CBT]).  Pharmacologic treatments can be useful for managing specific symptoms, including insomnia (eg, melatonin, zolpidem) and anxiety/depression (eg, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors).

Long-term treatment and prognosis



Long-term management of cannabis use disorder often requires a combination of interventions.  These include CBT, group counseling, and, occasionally, pharmacotherapy (eg, topiramate, gabapentin) to reduce cravings.  Many people recover with proper treatment and psychosocial support, but the risk for relapse is high without behavioral intervention.

Summary



Cannabis is a widely used recreational drug that produces effects such as euphoria, relaxation, altered time perception, increased appetite, and conjunctival injection.  Cannabis use disorder is characterized by persistent drug use despite negative consequences (eg, social or occupational impairments).  Prolonged cannabis use may lead to cognitive deficits, memory impairment, decreased motivation, and mood disturbances.  On cessation, individuals with chronic use may experience withdrawal symptoms, such as irritability, depression, insomnia, and craving.
